byline.contributor: Jodi Rudoren reported from Jerusalem, and Michael D. Shear from Washington. Diaa Hadid contributed reporting from Jerusalem, and Julie Hirschfeld Davis from Washington.
byline.original: By JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, in first interview since his re-election, says he had not meant to reverse his endorsement in 2009 speech of two-state solution to Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but that it is not possible currently; Pres Obama waits nearly two days before making congratulatory phone call to Netanyahu, as his administration remains angry over Israeli leader's pre-election remarks.
lead_paragraph: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he had not intended to reverse his endorsement in a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline.main: Israel’s Netanyahu Reopens Door to Palestinian State, but White House Is Unimpressed
headline.print_headline: Israeli Leader Backs Off Stand on 2-State Option

snippet: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he had not intended to reverse his endorsement in a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
